creditline: The John R. Van Derlip Fund
description: standing blonde little girl with green eyes, wearing a pink dress with white polka dots, pink hair ribbon, white socks with pink trim, and red shoes, and holds a purple flower in her PR hand; girl has blank facial expression; girl stands in front of a wall mural with a blue and yellow dragon against a red ground with glitter highlights against a red ground with bold black Chinese characters; shiny black floor
signed: signed, titled and dated on reverse
text: Portrait of a Girl is among Joan Brown’s most startling and engaging self-portraits, a memory picture, allegorical and mysterious. It is based on two photographs of Brown as a child. The Chinese dragon screen that looms behind her is based on a black-and-white illustration in a book Brown owned. She imaginatively combined her image and the screen, presenting them together to establish a tension between the two elements that provokes the viewer to muse on the relationship between Brown as a little girl and the menacing dragon.
title: Portrait of a Girl
